page.title: 06Local History in Johnstone
page.content: The most significant aspects of Johnstone's local history centre round the mining and textile industries. Freestone and whin quarries have been in Johnstone since 1634. Although there were only 2 coalmines the Benston Pit had a coal seam 100' wide. The Auchenlodment Pit was closed after a flooding disaster killing 5 miners in 1818. In 1860 the closure of Benston Pit due to its second flooding disaster ended coal mining in the area. About 1721, Christian Shaw smuggled looms into Scotland from Holland. By 1735 the linen trade was booming. On the Black Cart River, an important early source of power, there stands a good example of a linen mill, now Smith & McLaurins Paper Mill. Johnstone Castle tower home of George Houston still stands as does an 1896 tower marking site of ancient castle.
